Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
 
Proposal  Support to the Government of Pakistan for the Second Generation of 
Capital Market Reform Program through (i) a program loan of $400 million 
and (ii) a technical assistance (TA) grant of $1 million to support program 
implementation. 
 
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention

Themes:  Sustainable  economic  growth,  capacity  development,

Rationale  The  growth  and  development  of  well-functioning  capital  markets, 
particularly  equity  and  long-term  debt  (bonds),  generates  significant 
benefits. Capital markets facilitate the mobilization of financial resources 
and  their  efficient  allocation  into  productive  investments  by  providing 
efficient  savings  vehicles  for  retail  and  institutional  investors  and 
diversifying funding sources for enterprises. Diversification also makes the 
corporate and financial sectors more robust to shocks, which enhances 
the sustainability of economic development.  
 
Pakistan has made progress with capital market reforms since the 1990s. 
The enabling legal, regulatory, and institutional framework for the capital 
market has been strengthened; the financial health of most ailing financial 
institutions restored; a large number of state-owned institutions have been 
privatized;  and  competition  invigorated.  However,  domestic  capital 
markets do not yet play a significant role in financial intermediation and 
resource mobilization.  
 
Building on achievements thus far, the Government is planning to launch a 
second generation of capital market reforms to facilitate mobilization of 
financial resources for productive investment and employment generation. 
These reforms also aim at a balanced development of the financial sector, 
which will reduce systemic vulnerabilities in a bank-dominated financial 
system.

ii   
The  Government  plans  to  put  special  emphasis  on  strengthening  the 
enabling  environment  for  pension  funds  and  other  nonbank  financial 
institutions,  given  the  strong  causal  relationship  between  the  level  of 
development  of  institutional  investors  and  the  deepening  of  capital 
markets. While limited supply of suitable assets, including corporate equity 
and debt, clearly hampers the development of institutional investors, the 
relative  underdevelopment  of  contractual  savings  schemes  offered  by 
institutional investors limits the demand for securities.  
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  supported  financial  sector 
reforms in Pakistan since mid-1990s through two significant programs. 
The Government has requested ADB’s support for its renewed capital 
market development initiative in continuation of past assistance. A quick-
disbursing program will help leverage the Government’s policy reforms 
and provide necessary financial resources. 
 
Impact and  The impact of the Program will be enhanced economic growth through a 
Outcome  more efficient and balanced financial system. The Program’s outcome will 
  be  increased  resource  mobilization  through  the  capital  markets  for 
productive investment and employment generation by providing efficient 
savings  vehicles  for  retail  and  institutional  investors,  and  diversified 
funding sources for enterprises. Such diversification will also make the 
corporate and financial sectors more resilient to shocks.  
 
The Program will (i) support the development of institutional investors to 
facilitate  long-term  capital  formation  and  increase  the  demand  for 
securities, (ii) improve the efficiency of securities markets to increase the 
supply  of  corporate  securities  and  optimize  the  allocation  of  financial 
resources into productive investment, and (iii) strengthen the governance 
of capital markets to improve market transparency and protect investors. 
 
Financing Plan  ADB will support the Government’s second generation of capital market 
reforms under the Program by providing a program loan of $400 million 
from the ordinary capital resources of ADB under ADB’s London interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The loan will have a 15-year 
term, including a grace period of 3 years, an interest rate determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment 
charge of 0.75% per year, and such other terms and conditions as set 
forth in the draft Loan Agreement.  
 
Program Period  The Program will be completed in 2 years, by 30 June 2009. The loan will

released following satisfaction of the first tranche release conditions and 
after loan effectiveness. The second tranche of $200 million is expected to 
be released between 6 and 18 months after release of the first tranche 
subject to the Government meeting the conditions specified for its release.

Implementation  The Government will establish a Program Coordination Unit in the Ministry 
Arrangements  of Finance to coordinate program implementation. The unit will cooperate 
closely with the Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan and 
Ministry of Privatization, which will act as the implementing agencies. 
   
Counterpart  The Government will ensure that the local currency funds generated by 
Funds  the loan are used to (i) support the costs of reforms to be initiated and 
implemented under the Program, and (ii) finance expenditures for  general

Program Benefits  The  Program  will  facilitate  the  mobilization  of  financial  resources  for 
and Beneficiaries  productive  investment  and  employment  generation  by  supporting  the 
  development of corporate bond and equity capital markets in Pakistan. It 
will help to ensure balanced development of the financial sector, which will 
reduce systemic vulnerabilities in the bank-dominated financial system.  
 
The policy and regulatory reforms supported under the Program will help 
to significantly increase the number of corporate bond and equity issues, 
both primary and secondary. This will facilitate the mobilization of financial 
resources for long-term private sector investment, including infrastructure 
investment. Further, the reforms will facilitate capital mobilization through 
strengthening and increasing contractual savings. This is beneficial not 
only from a social security point of view; it will also increase and stabilize 
the  demand  for  securities  issued  by  the  private  sector  and  the 
Government. 
 
The  Program  will  enhance  market  efficiency  and  transparency,  and 
improve investor protection by strengthening governance of the capital 
market. Further, the program-supported reforms will help fight corruption 
by (i) strengthening the independence, accountability, and transparency of 
the regulatory body in charge of securities markets; and (ii) increasing the 
transparency  of  state-owned  enterprise  privatization  through  a  capital 
market oriented privatization policy. 
 
The Program will increase the competitiveness of financial groups and the 
effectiveness of financial sector regulation and supervision in line with 
international best practices, which will in turn reduce systemic risks.  
 
The capital market-oriented privatization approach supported under the 
Program will also (i) help increase budget revenues, since investors will 
tend  to  pay  more  for  shares  if  an  individual  offer  is  embedded  in  a 
transparent and credible overall privatization strategy; (ii) support capital 
market  development  by  increasing  liquidity;  and  (iii)  improve  the 
performance of enterprises by infusing greater market discipline amongst 
companies. 
 
Risks and  Macroeconomic  stability  is  essential  for  financial  sector  development. 
Assumptions  Macroeconomic risks are mitigated by prudent fiscal and monetary policies 
and  high  expected  economic  growth  rates.  Pakistan  has  made  good 
progress on these fronts in recent years. Moving forward, the Program has

to assume that (i) Pakistan will not suffer from any adverse geopolitical 
changes  affecting  its  external  and  internal  stability,  and  (ii)  that  the 
successive Governments will remain strongly committed to capital market 
reforms. The presidential elections scheduled for late 2007 may result in 
policy changes in some areas. However, economic policies are unlikely to 
be  fundamentally  changed,  given  the  high  degree  of  continuity  in 
economic policy making in Pakistan over the last decade and the broad 
consensus for economic reforms, including financial sector reform. 
 
Another risk is that draft legislation will be enacted with substantial delays 
and/or may not be in line with international best practice due to vested 
interest and lack of understanding by lawmakers. To minimize this risk, 
legislative changes related to the Program were drafted during program 
preparation  or  will  be  drafted  under  the  TA  to  ensure  quality  of  the 
legislation. Further, TA will be provided to support the Government in 
undertaking and sustaining stakeholder consultations. 
 
Good  regulatory  governance  cannot  be  sustained  without  good  public 
sector governance in general. The latter includes effective measures to 
reduce  corruption,  a  sound  approach  to  competition  policies,  effective 
legal and judicial systems, and an arm’s-length approach to government 
ownership. A successful continuation of the Government’s anticorruption 
and private sector development policies is therefore a critical pre-condition 
for reaching the Program’s objectives.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Second  Generation  of  Capital  Market  Reform 
Program (the Program). The report also describes a proposed technical assistance (TA) grant 
for Supporting the Second Generation of Capital Market Reform Program and, if the Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will 
approve the TA. The design and monitoring framework for the Program is in Appendix 1. 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 
2.  The Pakistan economy grew strongly over the past 4 years, at an average rate of 6.5%. 
Private  consumption,  boosted  by  rapid  expansion  in  consumer  credit  and  higher  worker’s 
remittances, was a lead contributor to economic growth. The rise of investment spending to 
20%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  supported  by  improved  business  confidence  and 
increasing  inflows  of  foreign  direct  investment  also  contributed.  However,  national  savings 
declined due to rising consumer demand, negative real interest rates on bank deposits, and 
scarcity of alternative savings vehicles. Strong macroeconomic policies, high GDP growth, 
increases in pro-poor spending, and burgeoning workers’ remittances all contributed to a steep 
decline in the incidence of poverty and the unemployment rate. Since Fiscal Year (FY) 2005, the 
Government has pursued a pro-growth fiscal policy. Development outlays have risen sharply. 
Spending in pro-poor sectors increased from 4.8% of GDP in fiscal year (FY) 2005 to 5.6% the 
following year. Alongside this, unplanned spending on relief and reconstruction in areas affected 
by  the  devastating  October  2005  earthquake  also  contributed  to  an  increase  in  public 
expenditures. 
3.  Strong  demand  for  goods  and  services  has  outstripped  supply  and  generated 
inflationary pressures. However, after peaking in 2005 at above 11%, annual inflation declined 
to 6.6% in January 2007 as a result of tighter monetary policy. The exchange rate of the 
Pakistan rupee was kept at parity with the US dollar. With higher domestic inflation, the real 
exchange  rate  has,  therefore,  increased.  This,  together  with  strong  domestic  demand, 
contributed to a significant deterioration in the current account of the balance of payments. In 
FY2006, the current account deficit (excluding official transfers) more than tripled to $5.7 billion 
or 4.4% of GDP. The deficit was mainly financed through foreign direct investment inflows and 
concessional  loans  from  multilateral  development  agencies.  The  current  account  deficit 
continued  to  widen  in  FY2007.  This  development  has  provided  strong  incentives  for  the 
Government  to  continue  structural  reforms,  including  privatization,  to  strengthen  the 
competitiveness of exports and attract foreign investment. However, it has also increased the 
short-term need for balance of payment support. Pakistan’s external debt increased by $1.6 
billion to $36.9 billion in the second half of 2006. As a percentage of GDP, external debt 
remained on a downward trajectory, declining to 25.4% in December 2006 from 31% in FY2005. 
This trend is forecast to continue under the debt sustainability framework of the International 
Monetary Fund for Pakistan for the period from FY2001 to FY2010.2

III.  THE CAPITAL MARKET: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
4.  The growth and development of well-functioning capital markets, particularly markets for 
equity and long-term debt (bonds), generate significant economic benefits. Capital markets 
facilitate the mobilization of financial resources and their efficient allocation into productive 
investments by providing efficient savings vehicles for retail and institutional investors, and 
diversifying funding sources for enterprises. This diversification also makes the corporate and 
financial sectors more resilient to shocks, which enhances the sustainability of development. 
5.  Pakistan has made progress with capital market reforms since 1998, when a year-long 
economic and financial crisis culminated in a breakdown of the capital market. Since then, with 
support  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  the  enabling  legal,  regulatory,  and 
institutional framework for the capital market has been strengthened; the financial health of most 
ailing financial institutions restored; a large number of state-owned institutions privatized; and 
competition invigorated. Yet, domestic capital markets do not play a significant role in financial 
intermediation and resource mobilization.  
6.  This is confirmed by macroeconomic data: In FY2005, national savings amounted to 
16.4% of GDP in Pakistan, i.e., the same level as in FY2000 (Table 1). The percentage of 
savings intermediated by the financial system amounted to 7.5% of GDP (46% of national 
savings) in FY2005, up from 4.8% of GDP (29% of national savings) in FY2000. However, this 
increase  was  due  to  successful  banking  reforms,  which  resulted  in  enhanced  banking 
intermediation.  In  contrast,  intermediation  through  nonbank  financial  institutions  (NBFIs) 
declined over the last 6 years.

7.  Sector data support this view: Total financial sector assets amounted to 79% of GDP in 
2005 ($87 billion equivalent), up from 73% ($50 billion) in 2001. Over the same period, the 
share of banking assets within the financial sector increased from 63.7% to 70.4%, while the 
share of the state-owned Central Directorate of National Savings, i.e., the biggest institutional 
investor in the country, fell from 25.7% to 18.1% of total financial sector assets. All other NBFIs 
together accounted for 11.6% of total financial sector assets in FY2005, marginally up from 
10.5% in FY2001. In conclusion, Pakistan’s financial sector is less balanced now than 6 years 
ago. Banking has gained ground in relative as well as absolute terms. 
 
8.  In contrast, capital market instruments are not yet an important source of corporate 
finance. Capital raised through equity and bond issues together was equivalent to only 0.3% of 
GDP in 2005. Banking products are still much more relevant for resource mobilization and

1.  Structure and Institutions 
10.  Pakistan’s  capital  market  comprises  three  stock  exchanges  based  in  Karachi, 
Islamabad, and Lahore; a National Clearing and Settlement System; a  Central Depositary 
Company; about 300 brokers; and two rating agencies. All three exchanges are fully private and 
mutually owned by their broker members. However, preparations for the demutualization of all 
three exchanges are under way. More than 700 of the approximately 2,800 registered public 
companies are listed at one or more stock exchanges. Only listed companies can make public 
issuance of securities in Pakistan. Further, there is a large number of NBFIs including 54 
insurance  companies,  40  mutual  funds,  5  development  financial  institutions,  8  investment 
banks, 20 leasing companies, and others. Two state-owned institutions, the Central Directorate 
of National Savings and State Life Insurance Company, are the biggest institutional investors. 
11.  Since the 1990s the NBFI sector has transformed rapidly. The total number of NBFIs 
has declined significantly and their financial soundness has improved. The share of state-owned 
NBFIs has declined, but is still substantial. In June 2006, insurance companies accounted for 
about 34% of total NBFI assets, mutual funds 23%, and development financial institutions 18%. 
State-owned institutions account for about 77% of total insurance assets and 51% of total 
mutual  fund  assets.  Most  development  financial  institutions  are  foreign  sponsored.  Private 
pension funds have yet to appear as a class of institutional investors in Pakistan. However, 
some large private companies sponsor a variety of provident funds and pension schemes. 
12.  Banks are increasingly engaged in the capital market as issuer, investor, and provider of 
investment  banking  services.  A  number  of  banks  have  established  investment  banking 
departments  or  subsidiaries,  and  acquired  brokerage  houses.  Similarly,  some  NBFIs  and 
brokers  have  acquired  commercial  banks.  Another  trend  is  the  formation  of  groups  of 
companies that include various financial institutions. Thus, a relatively complex web of corporate 
structures is emerging in Pakistan, which calls for a sound policy and regulatory environment.

2.  Regulation and Supervision 
13.  The Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan (SECP) regulates and supervises 
the activities of corporate entities and NBFIs under the 1984 Companies Ordinance, the 1969 
Securities Ordnance, and a number of other laws, including the 2000 Insurance Ordinance. 
SECP was set up in pursuance to the 1997 SECP Act. While SECP’s mandate was initially 
restricted to securities markets, responsibility for insurance and other NBFIs has been added 
over time. However, with regard to insurance, SECP shares its regulatory powers with the 
Ministry of Commerce. Commercial banks are regulated and supervised by the State Bank of 
Pakistan (SBP). 
3.  Overall Market Development Trends 
14.  Since 2001, equity market capitalization and share prices have increased substantially in 
Pakistan  with  annual  growth  rates  averaging  more  than  50%.  Equity  market  capitalization 
increased from 9% of GDP in 2001 to 35% in 2006 ($45.5 billion equivalent). However, this was 
lower than in other Asian markets (Table 2). 
15.  The increase in market capitalization in Pakistan was largely the result of the listing of a 
number of large state-owned enterprises (SOEs) together with the growth in share prices rather 
than  successful  capital  mobilization  through  equity  issues  (para.16).  Further,  the  market 
remains narrow. The 10 largest companies alone account for 55% of market capitalization. 
However, only an average of 20% of their shares has been floated. This, like in other countries 
in the region, is an important factor behind low market liquidity.  
16.  While other countries in the region face similar problems with market outreach, Pakistan 
is clearly lagging in terms of resource mobilization through the capital market. In 2005, for 
instance,  Pakistani  companies  issued  some  $68  million  equivalent  in  new  capital.  This 
compares to $19.1 billion in India, $4 billion in the People’s Republic of China, $3.7 in Thailand, 
$2 billion in Malaysia, $1 billion in Indonesia, and $900 million in the Philippines. The amounts 
of equity capital raised in Pakistan over the preceding years were even lower. Similarly, only 
$203 million equivalent of capital was raised through corporate bond issues in Pakistan in 2005. 
Nevertheless, the number of bond issues has clearly increased as compared with the 1990s. 
While 9 corporate bonds were issued in 1995–1999, 68 corporate bonds were issued in 2000–
2005. 
17.  The market for government bonds is much larger than that for corporate bonds. Pakistan 
investment  bonds  (PIBs)  are  by  far  the  most  significant  type  of  securities  issued  by  the 
Government, with a 91% share of total outstanding federal government bonds (June 2005). In 
June 2006, $5.1 billion equivalent (about 4% of GDP) of PIBs were in circulation. Maturities in 
circulation are 3, 5, 10, 20, and 30 years. This compares to a maximum maturity period of 
7 years for corporate bonds.  
18.  Derivative markets are almost nonexistent in Pakistan (with the exception of currency 
futures and 1-month single-share futures) due to the underdevelopment of the underlying equity 
and bond markets. 
4.  Factors Driving the Market 
19.  Privatization  through  stock  exchanges  has  been  a  major  factor  driving  the  capital 
market,  together  with  macroeconomic  stabilization,  and—to  a  lesser  degree—international 
investor diversification, the development of domestic institutional investors, and other reforms.

5 
   
20.  The Government has divested a large number of SOEs since the 1990s, some by listing 
and partial privatization through the stock exchange(s). This has clearly been the main driving 
force  for  market  capitalization  and  share  prices.  Among  the  10  largest  listed  companies 
(para.15) are six SOEs, which together account for 42% of total market capitalization. Shares of 
SOEs offered for sale through the stock market are typically heavily oversubscribed, given the 
expectation of subsequent increases in share prices which have frequently been substantial. 
21.  Undeniable progress has been made with other structural reforms that have led to 
substantial changes such as (i) a higher share of private enterprises in- and outside the financial 
sector; (ii) consolidation of the NBFI subsector, which now consists of a smaller number of 
better  capitalized  and  more  efficiently  managed  entities;  and  (iii)  a  better  regulatory  and 
institutional framework for capital markets. Further, efforts are under way to enhance corporate 
governance and disclosure, which is important because both figure prominently in investment 
decisions. On the technical side, significant progress has been made in establishing electronic 
clearing  and  settlement  systems.  However,  that  has  yet  to  turn  the  capital  market  into  a 
significant source of capital formation. Moderate progress has, nevertheless, been made, as 
evidenced  by  the  increased  number  of  securities  issues.  SBP’s  policy  to  increase  capital 
requirements for banks has led a number of banks to raise capital through bond issues. 
22.  High  economic  growth,  consumer  demand,  and  higher  corporate  earnings  have 
facilitated capital market development as compared with the 1990s. The same applies to the 
monetary  environment.  The  exchange  rate  and  inflation  outlook  stabilized  after  1999, 
lengthening  time  horizons  and  reducing  the  cost  of  borrowing.  Interest  rates  declined 
significantly during 2001–2003. Since 2004, inflation has picked up again and its outlook is less 
stable. This had a negative impact on the market for government bonds, particularly in 2005. 
The impact of higher and more volatile inflation and rising interest rates on the corporate bond 
market was mitigated by increasingly using floating rates for newly issued corporate bonds. 
23.  Domestic institutional investors such as mutual funds or insurance companies have 
emerged as a relatively new force in the financial sector. The mutual funds subsector remains 
small relative to other countries in the region. Individual investors account for the bulk of 
exchange trading. However, in 2005, total assets of mutual funds amounted to $2.3 billion. As 
such, they are a relevant player. Equity funds now account for 85% of total assets under 
management of mutual funds. In contrast, most assets of insurance companies are invested in 
government  bonds,  only  16%  in  equity.  Investment  of  the  Central  Directorate  of  National 
Savings and the Old Age Benefits Institution is also concentrated in government securities. 
24.  The investor base of Pakistan issuers of securities is not restricted to domestic investors. 
Foreign portfolio investment rose to $334 million during FY2006, up from an aggregate inflow of 
$202 million over the preceding 3 years. The increasing inflow of portfolio investment is in line 
with international and regional trends. One underlying factor is the explosion of resources 
mobilized by dedicated emerging market funds. Another is that controls on foreign investment in 
shares and bonds have been substantially loosened. Pakistani companies can also raise capital 
internationally. Two Pakistani companies have taken this step so far by listing on the London 
Stock Exchange in late-2006.  
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Government Strategy 
25.  Pakistan does not yet have an integrated financial sector development strategy, though 
SBP is currently drafting one. Key planning documents such as the Government’s Medium-

6     
   
Term Development Framework for 2005–2010,3 however, list private sector growth, capital 
market development, and private participation in infrastructure (which requires long-term debt 
financing through bonds) as important goals. These goals are likely to be achieved as the 
Government  remains  committed  to  a  next  generation  reform  agenda  in  banking  (further 
consolidation,  introduction  of  risk-based  supervision)  and  capital  markets  (adding  depth  to 
market development).  
26.  Following successful banking reforms, the Government intends to accelerate capital 
market reforms to turn corporate securities into a relevant source for long-term finance and 
ensure a balanced development of the financial sector. Besides deepening capital markets and 
introducing  new  financing  instruments,  the  Government  is  keen  to  promote  new  savings 
instruments, in particular pension products, to increase low domestic savings—a key constraint 
to mobilizing financial resources for higher investment. The Government also aims to strengthen 
the  institutional  framework  for  sector  governance  by  establishing  a  financial  services 
commission for the regulation and supervision of NBFIs and services. 
2.   Issues and Opportunities 
27.  Key issues, constraints, and opportunities facing the development of capital markets in 
Pakistan include (i) weak enabling environment for nonbank financial companies4, (ii) lack of a 
regulatory  framework  for  private  pension  funds,  (iii)  policy  and  regulatory  constraints  for 
corporate  bond  issues,  (iv)  high  equity  market  volatility  and  small  public  float,  (v)  weak 
institutional framework for capital market regulation and supervision, (vi) difficulties supervising 
financial groups, (vii) weak securities market legislation, and (viii) market fragmentation. 
28.  Figure  1  provides  a  schematic  illustration  of  these  issues  and  constraints  for  the 
developing institutional investors, increasing the supply of securities, and establishing a sound 
framework for sector governance and investor protection.  
a.  Underdevelopment of Institutional Investors Constrains Long-Term 
Capital Formation and Demand for Securities 
29.  While lack of suitable assets, including corporate equity and debt (bonds), has clearly 
hampered  the  development  of  institutional  investors,  the  relative  underdevelopment  of 
contractual savings inhibits, in turn, the development of equity and bond markets. Studies 
elsewhere show a particularly strong causal relationship between the level of development of 
funded private pension schemes and life insurance, and the deepening of the capital market. 
 
30.  Weak Enabling Environment for Nonbank Financial Companies. The legal status of 
nonbank financial companies, including important classes of institutional investors such as 
mutual funds, investment banks, and others, is recognized in the 1984 Companies Ordinance. 
However, the Companies Ordinance does not provide a legal mandate for SECP for licensing, 
prudential regulation, and supervision of such companies. This is a serious constraint for the 
sound development of nonbank financial companies, since it limiting the scope for establishing 
and enforcing a sound regulatory framework. Typically, regulation and supervision of such 
companies would be covered under a substantive law such as exists in Pakistan for securities 
markets and the insurance industry.

31.  Mutual funds are the single most important type of institutional investors in Pakistan. The 
state-owned National Investment Trust (NIT) is by far the largest mutual fund, with assets of 
$1.4 billion under management, equivalent to 37% of total assets of the mutual fund industry (as 
of April 2007). NIT’s dominating market position and implicit credit guarantee as a state-owned 
company constrain the development of private sector mutual funds by distorting competition. 
 
32.  Lack  of  Regulatory  Framework  for  Private  Pension  Funds.  The  introduction  of 
private pension schemes could have a significant positive impact on the development of equity 
and  bond  markets,  and  vice  versa.  However,  this  requires  such  schemes  to  be  properly 
regulated to protect the pension savings of individuals. In Pakistan, a regulatory framework for 
voluntary contribution-funded private pension schemes has yet to be established. The same 
applies to employer-sponsored pension arrangements, for which SECP is assigned authority (as 
for other private pension products). However, these schemes currently have no direct oversight 
or supervision other than by tax authorities. This constitutes a regulatory gap that is potentially 
dangerous as it leaves participants unprotected. 
 
b.   Underdeveloped Market for Corporate Securities Limits Securities 
Supply  
33.  As in many other countries, Pakistan’s financial sector is dominated by banks. However, 
unlike most other countries, bank dominance has increased over the last 5 years (para. 7). 
Overreliance on the limited range of banking services and products is not only a constraint for 
savings mobilization and investment finance, it also poses considerable risks to the stability of 
the financial sector and the economy in total as experienced during the Asian financial crisis. 
 
34.  Regulatory and Policy Constraints on Corporate Bond Issues. Corporate bonds are 
normally priced at a premium over a risk-free rate of return (yield) on government bonds or other 
benchmark debt instrument with comparable maturity. The Government issues a considerable 
volume of debt instruments. However, these instruments are mostly not tradable (tradable 
government  securities  such  as  PIBs  or  treasury  bills  together  accounted  for  only  32%  of 
outstanding debt in June 2006). Further, the terms of tradable government securities, including 
maturity periods, and the volume of issues vary considerably. Both factors have undermined 
efforts to build a government benchmark yield curve. Consequently, the pricing of corporate 
bonds is very difficult, which in turn clearly impedes corporate bond market development. 
 
35.  The 1899 Stamp Duty Act gives provincial authorities the right to levy a stamp duty on 
term finance certificates, i.e., corporate bonds. Until 2005, the rate was uniformly 0.15% of the 
issued volume or Rs1,000,000 ($17,000 equivalent), whichever is lower. In the Province of the 
Punjab this rate was reduced to 0.05% through the 2006 budget act. However, the Government 
of Punjab decided to levy the duty annually rather than just once. This means the rate is higher 
now for bonds with a maturity longer than 2 years. The Sindh Provincial Government only 
marginally reduced the duty for secondary issues. The Islamabad Capital Territory has not 
changed the original rates from 0.15%. 
 
36.  Stamp duties are a serious policy distortion that undermines the Government’s objective 
to  achieve  balanced  development  of  the  financial  sector.  The  duties  increase  the  cost  of 
corporate bond issues and lower their competitiveness as compared with bank loans, which are 
not taxed. This is a key reason why the average amount of public corporate bond issues has 
been at around $20 million for years, which appears very high as compared with the size of 
typical investment projects in the country. Smaller volumes are not competitive financially due to

the  stamp  duty  (and  other  regulatory  constraints  that  increase  the  cost  of  issuing  bonds; 
paras.37–38). Further, annual levies clearly act as a disincentive for the issuance of long-term 
bonds.  This  significantly  undermines  the  Government’s  objective  to  attract  private  sector 
participation  in  infrastructure,  where  long-term  debt  finance  (through  bonds)  is  particularly 
important. From a fiscal revenue perspective, stamp duties on corporate bonds are insignificant, 
given the small number of bonds issued (only six public bond issues in FY2006, for instance). 
 
37.  SECP has not authorized trading in publicly offered corporate bonds outside the stock 
exchanges. Instead, corporate bonds are required to be listed and traded within an electronic 
trading system established at the exchanges. This constrains bond market development, since it 
increases the cost of issuing bonds (in the form of listing and rating fees) without generating 
benefits. As debt instruments, corporate bonds are typically bought by institutional investors 
rather than retail investors. Further, even in mature financial markets, bonds are typically held 
until maturity and traded only infrequently (normally by phone through an informal over-the-
counter market). Therefore, forcing corporate bonds into listing and trading on a formal trading 
platform, essentially designed for a listed share market with a large order flow from retail 
investors, makes little sense. 
 
38.  Issuing corporate bonds involves cost in the form of registration fees and other charges 
that may be levied by the regulatory body. Further, the registration process takes time. The 
regulatory framework for bond issues should strike a balance between the public interest of 
investor protection, which is the key justification for regulation, and the need to make bonds a 
competitive instrument for investment finance. “Shelf-registration”5 of bonds (and equity), which 
helps to strike this balance, has been international practice for many years. However, securities 
market  regulation  in  Pakistan  does  not  support  the  concept  of  shelf  registration.  This 
significantly reduces the competitiveness of bonds as a means of investment finance. 
 
39.  High interest payments for instruments offered by the Government’s National Savings 
Scheme (NSS), which is administered by the Central Directorate of National Savings, hindered 
bond market development for years. As a step toward addressing the problem, the authorities 
introduced a formula linking interest on NSS instruments to yields on PIBs. However, NSS 
instruments  still  appear  attractive  since  their  pricing  fails  to  take  into  account  that  NSS 
instruments  can  be  redeemed  any  time  without  redemption  charges,  whereas  selling 
instruments with comparable yields involves such charges and/or other costs. Further, another 
step taken (in March 2000) to provide equal opportunities for corporate bonds was a ban on 
institutional investment in NSS instruments. This ban helped to increase the number of public 
corporate  bond  issues  significantly.  However,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  reversed  this 
decision in late 2006 so that institutional investors are able to invest in NSS instruments again.  
 
40.  Overall, given the large total volume of NSS instruments (which account for 41% of 
government debt) and their pricing, institutional investment in NSS instruments crowds out long-
term investment in corporate bonds. Further, issuing a large percentage of government debt in 
the form of NSS bonds undermines the Government’s efforts to build a benchmark yield curve 
for corporate debt by establishing a liquid market for treasury bills and PIBs. 
 
41.  High Equity Market Volatility and Small Public Float. The Pakistan stock market is 
highly volatile. This is partly due to a high volume of speculative short-term individual investment 
in shares. Following the increase of the capital value tax on all stock market transactions at the

42.  Another factor explaining high stock market volatility is the thin public float (shares 
available for trading) of the largest listed companies. This is mainly the result of the existing 
privatization policy that foresees an initial public offering (IPO) of only a limited number of SOE 
shares, usually 5%–10% of the total, to establish a market price. This market price can then be 
taken as a reference point for subsequent sales of larger share packages to strategic investors.  
 
43.  However, in many cases, the subsequent privatization to a strategic investor occurs with 
a substantial delay, if at all. This is primarily due to increasing public opposition against this 
approach,  which  is  perceived  as  not  sufficiently  transparent  and,  consequently  prone  to 
corruption and often subject to public interest litigation.6 In fact, while the current approach to 
privatization though an IPO and subsequent sale to a strategic investor may have merits with 
regard to some SOEs, it fails to acknowledge that well-prepared, sequenced sales of blocks of 
SOE shares to the public can increase the transparency of privatization, strengthen governance 
and performance of SOEs, and maximize the returns of the sales of state assets over the 
medium and long term. The present approach also fails to take into account its negative impact 
on market liquidity and volatility, and thus capital market development. While many IPOs of 
SOEs seem to be undertaken professionally, they are deal-driven and not embedded in a well-
designed overall privatization strategy. 
 
c.  Weak  Capital  Market  Governance  Results  in  Poor  Market 
Transparency and Weak Investor Protection 
44.  Weak Institutional Framework for Regulation and Supervision. SECP has, over 
time, been assigned responsibility for the regulation and supervision of the securities market 
and most categories of NBFIs. However, a number of weaknesses in the structural and legal 
framework affect effective prudential or market conduct regulation by the SECP. The overall 
enabling legislation, especially the 1997 SECP law, does not provide adequate independence 
and accountability required for SECP to effectively instill and oversee implementation of good 
governance for the large part of the financial sector for which it is in charge. More specifically, 
SECP’s institutional independence is undermined by inadequate terms for the appointment and 
dismissal of senior personnel. Further, SECP’s governance structure mixes executive powers 
with responsibilities for policy making, and fails to assign responsibility for key aspects such as 
accounting, law, and policy making to distinct senior officials. Furthermore, SECP’s supervisory 
independence, i.e., its ability to exercise its judgment and powers in such matters as licensing, 
inspections,  sanctioning,  and  enforcement  of  sanctions  is  undermined  by  insufficient  legal 
protection for its staff in the performance of their duties.  
45.  With regard to proper accountability, without which independence cannot be effective, 
SECP primarily reports to MOF. This arrangement brings SECP under the direct control of the 
Government and undermines its independence, which is clearly inferior to one that creates a 
network  of  complementary  and  overlapping  checking  mechanisms  through  the  executive, 
legislative, and judicial branches of government, and the industry and public at large. Such a 
framework  would  ensure  that  none  of  these  stakeholders  control  SECP  entirely  (and 
undermines its independence), but SECP is nonetheless under public control.

46.  Nontransparent Financial Groups. Holding companies are permitted under the 1984 
Companies Ordinance. However, the actual formation of holding companies is impeded by tax 
policy distortions that can result in double taxation of corporate income of affiliated companies 
within a holding company.7 This is the main reason why only few of the approximately 60 groups 
of companies in Pakistan were established under a holding company. This is not only negative 
for the competitiveness of these groups, but also for financial sector regulation and supervision. 
SECP and SBP find it often difficult, if not impossible, to discern the actual owners of financial 
entities in a complex financial group; monitor transactions between financial institutions within 
the  group;  and  enforce  laws  and  regulations,  including  prudential  requirements.  This 
significantly increases systemic risks in the financial sector. 
47.  The structuring of groups that include banks and NBFIs under a holding company would 
allow  these  groups  to  attain  the  benefits  of  a  diversified  financial  services  provider  while 
strengthening the ability of the group to engage in sound risk management practices. Further, it 
would enable the regulatory body to require that prudential standards be calibrated with the risk 
of  undertaking  diversified  financial  business,  and  that  financial  and  operating  reporting 
requirements be in line with international best practices for all types of financial institutions 
included in the group. This is especially important in an emerging financial services environment 
where risk management skills and supervision capacity are relatively weak.  
48.  Weak  Securities  Market  Legislation.  The  1969  Securities  Ordinance  has  been 
frequently amended over time, but is still outdated in some major areas. Among its many 
weaknesses, it fails to provide SECP with sufficient investigative and enforcement powers (not 
addressed by the 1997 SECP Law) and lacks provisions governing important areas and aspects 
of  modern  securities  markets,  such  as  collective  investment  schemes  or  various  levels  of 
commitments for underwriting securities (“best efforts”). 
49.  Currently securities market regulation requires investment banks and brokers (or such 
divisions in commercial banks) to firmly commit to underwrite issues of securities they want to 
bring to the market for their clients. That means they guarantee to purchase by themselves the 
amount that cannot be placed with other investors, despite their “best efforts” to achieve this. 
This harbors significant risks to investment banks and brokers, particularly in the case of an 
IPO, which entails the sale of securities for which a market price is not available. Underwriters, 
therefore, tend to underprice IPOs, which lowers proceeds to the issuer. As a result, companies 
are very reluctant to raise capital through a stock exchange listing. 
50.  Further, the 1969 Securities Ordinance does not clearly define the concepts of private 
placement and public offers, and focuses on the regulation and supervision of stock exchanges 
and listed companies rather than public companies and public securities (whether or not they 
are listed). SECP’s legal powers over unlisted public companies and issues are, therefore, very 
limited. Even the corporate governance and disclosure standards for listed companies flow out 
of (voluntary) listing standards established by stock exchanges rather than the Securities Law. 
The law does not, as such, achieve a key objective of securities market legislation, i.e., to 
provide an adequate legal basis for investor protection, and thereby facilitate capital formation. 
51.  Uneven corporate governance and disclosure requirements for listed and unlisted public 
companies create regulatory arbitrage and disincentives for listing, which undermines investor 
protection. In Pakistan unlisted public companies can enjoy the benefits of being public (in the 
form  of  a  broader  investor  base),  while  avoiding  the  stricter  corporate  governance  and

52.  Untested Competence of Professional Market Participants. A growing retail investor 
base will require quality investor support services and better market information. At present, no 
mechanism is in place to increase professional standards and qualification of stock brokers, 
mutual  fund  sales  agents,  or  compliance  officers.  If  appropriate  training  and  certification 
programs were implemented, this would enhance professionalism in the securities markets and 
improve investor protection. In other jurisdictions, such training is normally provided by a private 
training  institute  or  a  self-regulatory  organization.  The  actual  tests  for  competence  are 
administered by the securities market regulator or a self-regulatory organization, which is best 
practice  in  many  countries.  With  the  expected  privatization  of  NIT-managed  funds,  the 
strengthening of the regulatory framework and establishment of a training and certification 
program for securities market professionals and other NBFI agents and intermediaries become 
especially important. 
53.  Market Fragmentation. Although the vast majority of listed securities are traded on 
more than one exchange in Pakistan, the market remains fragmented, which undermines its 
efficiency, particularly with regard to price discovery and investor confidence. This is mainly due 
to weak linkages between the exchanges. The three exchanges do not have any systematic 
exchange of price and other information. Self-regulation of the exchanges is weak, and no 
mechanism is in place to coordinate intermarket surveillance and development of a plan for 
sharing self-regulatory responsibilities. Brokers are not required to execute orders of their clients 
in  the  best  interests  of  the  latter  in  a  fair  and  transparent  manner.  Due  to  lack  of  price 
information from other exchanges, brokers are often not in the position to avail of quotations 
from other exchanges. Options for strengthening investor protection and efficiency of the market 
by  addressing  its  fragmentation  and  increasing  transparency  include  (i)  merge  the  three 
exchanges, or (ii) strengthen linkages between exchanges to achieve a unified national market 
system in securities, which would consist of several exchanges. The second is more realistic 
under the present circumstances.

4.   Lessons 
59.  Relevant lessons from ADB’s experience with program lending in general, and with 
financial sector development in particular, have been incorporated in the design of the proposed 
Program. An important lesson is that policy actions requiring comprehensive legal reforms can 
hamper program implementation, notwithstanding a government’s strong support for a program. 
Under the FMGP, the Government was required to draft or amend a total of nine laws.14 This 
was  partly  the  response  to  a  previous  neglect  of  legal  reforms.  However,  while  strong 
commitment of the Government’s executive branch for legal reforms under the FMGP was 
helpful  in  maintaining  implementing  agencies  and  the  Parliament  focused  on  proposed 
legislation, this could not ensure the timely preparation of all recommended pieces of legislation 
and their subsequent passage by the legislature. The laws covered complex technical issues, 
dealt with a range of vested interests and required extensive stakeholder consultations. The 
proposed Program will focus on just two key pieces of legislation, namely a new securities law 
and a law that codifies a consolidated nonbank financial regulatory agency. Further, TA will be 
provided  to  ensure  that  the  draft  laws  comply  with  international  standards,  and  provide 
assistance, as needed, throughout the legislative deliberation process.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
62.  The impact of the Program will be enhanced economic growth through a more efficient 
and  better  balanced  financial  system.  The  Program’s  outcome  will  be  increased  resource 
mobilization through the capital market for productive investment and employment generation 
by  providing  efficient  savings  vehicles  for  retail  and  institutional  investors  and  diversifying 
funding sources for enterprises. This diversification will also make the corporate and financial 
sector more resilient to shocks. More specifically, the Program will (i) support the development 
of institutional investors to facilitate long-term capital formation and increase the demand for 
securities, (ii) improve the efficiency of securities markets to increase the supply of corporate 
securities and optimize the allocation of financial resources into productive investment, and 
(iii) strengthen capital market governance to improve market transparency and protect investors.  
63.  To achieve its objectives, the Program will (i) strengthen the enabling environment for 
private  pension  funds  and  other  institutional  investors;  (ii)  address  policy  and  regulatory 
constraints to the development of corporate bond markets; (iii) increase equity market breadth 
and reduce its volatility; (vi) strengthen the institutional framework for sector supervision by 
transforming  SECP  into  the  Financial  Services  Commission  of  Pakistan  (FSCP)  for  the 
regulation and supervision of NBFIs; and (v) strengthen the governance of securities markets, 
market professionals, and public issuers. 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
64.  The policy actions supported under the Program build on (i) international capital market 
development  experience;  (ii)  international  best  practice  in  securities  market  regulation  and 
supervision as reflected in the objectives and principles of the International Organization of 
Securities Commissions; (iii) ongoing or planned policy, legal, and regulatory reform initiatives of 
the  Government;  and  (iv)  proposals  formulated  under  a  number  of  stakeholder  initiatives, 
including (a) the Working Group on Debt Market and Commercial Paper, (b) the Debt Capital 
Market Committee, (c) the Task Force on Review of Tax Laws of Holding Companies, and 
(d) an ongoing private sector initiative to establish the Securities Institute of Pakistan (SIP). The 
development policy letter and policy matrix for the Program are in Appendix 4. A program of this 
nature  requires  sound  macroeconomic  underpinning.  On  ADB’s  request,  the  International 
Monetary Fund has provided a summary assessment of recent macroeconomic developments, 
which is presented in Appendix 5.

1.  Support the Development of Institutional Investors to Facilitate Long-Term 
Capital Formation 
a.  Establish an Enabling Environment for Private Pension Funds 
65.  Under the Program, SECP is to (i) establish a regulatory framework, including prudential 
standards and implementation guidelines, for a voluntary private pension scheme (VPS), and 
(ii) authorize  qualified  financial  companies  to  offer  VPS  to  their  clients.  The  regulatory 
framework will ensure investor protection. Further, the Government is to broaden the base of 
eligible VPS participants to individuals beyond those with a national tax number (estimated at 
1.6 million) to enhance the outreach of the VPS. Making all national identity cardholders eligible, 
for instance, could help to include individuals working outside the country (estimated at 6 
million) or in areas that are tax exempt such as agriculture. Broadening the base of the VPS is 
not only desirable from a social protection point of view; it would also significantly increase 
capital mobilization and the business viability of the VPS. 
66.  Based on a review (with ADB TA) of existing employer-sponsored occupational pension 
schemes, SECP will issue best practice guidelines for such schemes under the Program. In 
doing so, SECP will benefit from its experience in establishing the VPS framework.  
67.  To expand the range of shares for investment by private pension funds, the Government 
is to offer SOE shares in the form of block sales to private pension funds, as is current practice 
with  other  institutional  investors.  Making  SOE  shares,  which  are  typically  oversubscribed, 
available for pension funds will provide additional incentives to the population for embarking into 
long-term contractual saving through participation in private pension schemes, and help to 
reduce market volatility by facilitating long-term institutional investment in shares. 
b.  Support the Development of Domestic Institutional Investors 
68.  Under the Program, the Government is to clarify SECP’s legal mandate for its powers, 
functions, and responsibilities over nonbank financial companies and their services. As an 
intermediate solution, the Government will make amendments to the Company Ordinance to 
empower SECP to regulate mutual funds and strengthen SECP’s powers to establish prudential 
requirements for nonbank financial companies. Subsequently, SECP will be able to actually 
strengthen  prudential  requirements  by  amending  the  2005  rules  for  nonbank  financial 
companies. Amendments have already been drafted and discussed with the industry. 
69.  Further under the Program, the Government will draft (with ADB TA) and submit to 
Parliament a distinct nonbank financial companies law. Provisions for mutual funds could be 
included in this law or, alternatively, in the Securities Law, given their importance for securities 
markets. Providing a solid legal foundation for the regulation and supervision of mutual funds is 
particularly important given the planned privatization of NIT, which will substantially increase the 
assets managed by private mutual funds. NIT privatization is an important objective of the 
Government under the Program, since it will  significantly accelerate competition in the mutual 
fund industry.

17 
   
2.  Improve the Efficiency of Securities Markets to Optimize the Allocation of 
Financial Resources 
a.  Facilitate the Development of Corporate Bond Markets 
70.  SECP established the Working Group on Debt Market and Commercial Paper in March 
2005  and  the  Debt  Capital  Market  Committee  in  June  2006,  both  with  broad  stakeholder 
participation.  The  objective  of  these  initiatives  was  to  identify  bond  market  development 
constraints and formulate proposals to address them. Under the Program the Government is to 
disseminate the report of the Debt Capital Market Committee, which includes key proposals 
made by the Working Group on Debt Market and Commercial Paper. This will help to build 
broad-based consensus about needed reforms. Subsequently, the Government is to implement 
key proposals formulated by these stakeholder initiatives (paras. 71–76). 
71.  MOF and SBP are to build a benchmark yield curve for corporate bonds to include yields 
of treasury bills and PIBs by standardizing their terms and issuing them at regular intervals. The 
amounts and maturities should be determined by market conditions and the Government’s debt 
management policy. The liquidity of the yield-curve should be enhanced over time by increasing 
the amounts of individual issues. 
72.  The Government is also recommended to work with provincial authorities to reduce the 
cost of issuing corporate securities by lowering the stamp duties for corporate bonds. This will 
reduce (or even eliminate, if the duty is reduced to zero) a policy distortion that discriminates 
corporate bonds against bank credits. Lowering stamp duties on corporate bonds will tend to 
increase the number of corporate bond issues and lengthen their maturity. This will have a 
significant positive impact on economic development in general and private-sector-financed 
infrastructure development in particular. 
73.  SECP is to abolish the regulatory requirement for public corporate bond issues to be 
listed on a stock exchange. Abolishing the listing requirement reduces the cost of issuing bonds, 
and should significantly increase the number of issues. The policy action does not have any 
negative implications: Despite the current requirement to list at the formal over-the-counter 
market, no corporate bonds are actually traded at this market. Abolishing the listing requirement 
does  not  suggest  that  greater  liquidity  of  a  secondary  market  for  corporate  bonds  is  not 
desirable. However, greater liquidity cannot be artificially induced by policies that do not reflect 
market conditions and fail to acknowledge the characteristics of corporate bonds compared with 
equity: Corporate bonds normally are priced at a premium over a risk-free rate of return of 
benchmark debt instruments with comparable maturities, while share prices are determined 
primarily by company-specific information.  
74.  Further, SECP is to introduce shelf-registration procedures for securities. Corporate 
bond issues should be allowed for registration for at least one year, during which issuers can 
obtain funds when market conditions are favorable.  
75.  Finally, the Government is recommended to establish an enabling environment for the 
creation of a limited secondary market among qualified institutional buyers for privately placed 
corporate bonds. Given their lower cost of issue and regulatory requirement, the number and 
total volume of such private placements is estimated to be higher than those of publicly issued 
bonds.  Allowing  limited  trading  in  these  instruments  would  increase  the  amount  of  assets 
available to institutional investors, which would reduce their dependence on investing in non-
tradable NSS instruments. Trading should be limited to qualified institutional buyers with the 
capacity and sophistication to assess the risks involved in investing in privately placed bonds.

18    
   
76.  As  a  second  step,  the  Government  is  asked  to  issue  tradable  Government  bonds 
through the NSS wide branch network, which will provide retail investors throughout the country 
with  a  means  for  accumulating  long-term  savings  through  investment  in  higher-yielding 
government bonds. The measure will have the additional benefit of increasing the volume of 
government securities in circulation, which would, in turn, help to achieve the objective of 
developing a benchmark yield curve. To provide incentives for institutional (and other) investors 
to invest into tradable instruments, the Government will ensure a lower rate of return for non-
tradable NSS instruments as compared with that of tradable Government bonds.  
b.  Increase Equity Market Breath and Reduce its Volatility 
77.  Under the Program, the Government is asked to continue the exemption from capital 
gains tax on income earned from individual investment in shares to facilitate long-term capital 
formation. To reduce the high volume of speculative short-term investment by individuals, the 
Government is to introduce a turnover tax on such investment.  
78.  Further,  the  Government  is  asked  to  develop,  with  ADB  TA,  a  policy  for  SOE 
privatization  through  stock  exchanges.  Such  privatization  should  take  into  account  market 
conditions and investor demand, and the need to achieve a balance between shares offered in 
international financial centers and shares offered domestically. The policy should be disclosed 
to the public to increase transparency. The potential benefits of a more capital market oriented 
privatization approach include (i) higher prices for shares and, thus, higher budget revenues, 
since  investors  will  tend  to  pay  more  for  shares  if  they  have  a  credible  expectation  that 
additional packages will be offered in the foreseeable future up to a specified minimum total of 
shares; (ii) increased market liquidity and lower volatility through a significant increase in supply 
of shares, which should facilitate overall capital market development, (iii) improved performance 
of enterprise managers by introducing market discipline to companies even if they are still partly 
state owned; and (iv) limiting the scope for corruption by increasing transparency of privatization 
and reducing discretion of civil servants involved. The policy will also allow the Privatization 
Commission to offer SOE shares through a book building process in line with international best 
practices to domestic institutional buyers and allow the use of shelf-registrations procedures, 
which will increase the efficiency of the process. 
79.  In developing a more stock-market-oriented privatization approach, the Government will 
be assisted by ADB in taking the experience of other counties into account, specifically the 
People’s Republic of China, Malaysia, and Viet Nam. 
3.  Strengthen  the  Governance  of  Capital  Markets  to  Improve  Market 
Transparency and Protect Investors 
a.  Strengthen the Institutional Framework for Sector Supervision 
80.  Under the Program SECP is to be converted into the Financial Services Commission of 
Pakistan (FSCP) in charge of regulation and supervision of NBFIs by clearly codifying its 
powers, functions, governance, and accountability in line with international best practices. In 
recent years, financial sector regulatory bodies have been granted greater independence in 
many countries to ensure that they can professionally perform their statutory functions in the 
public  interest  and  be  largely  free  from  political  interference.  An  agency  responsible  for 
regulation and supervision of NBFIs and markets should, in general, have authority and capacity 
comparable to that of the agency in charge of banking (and for similar reasons).

19 
   
81.  The Government is asked to draft and submit to Parliament a law codifying the FSCP. 
This law would establish FSCP, based on SECP, and strengthen its enforcement powers by 
enhancing its independence, governance, and accountability. The law should be a framework 
law that incorporates by reference to sector-specific laws (such as the laws governing securities 
markets  and  intermediaries,  insurance,  private  pension  funds,  and  nonbank  financial 
companies) FSCP’s powers to administer those laws. The establishment of FSCP does not 
preclude  further  integration  of  responsibility  for  regulation  and  supervision  of  banking  and 
nonbanking financial services at a later date (for which the framework law would have to be 
amended).  However,  given  the  substantive  capacity  building  needs  to  establish  a  fully 
consolidated financial sector agency and the considerable transaction cost typically involved in 
merging regulatory agencies with different cultures and capacity, this would be beyond the 
scope of the Program. 
82.  Given the urgency of a suitable governance arrangement for SECP, particularly for recruiting 
and  retaining  qualified  staff  and  senior  personnel,  the  Government  is  to  strengthen  SECP’s 
governance in the short term under existing law. SECP is to move to competitive remuneration for 
senior officers to fill all existing positions. Further, SECP is asked to designate specific positions for 
commissioners responsible for law, and accounting and auditing, given the importance of these 
areas for effective financial sector regulation and supervision. Furthermore, another commissioner 
should be charged with assessing the economic impact of regulatory initiatives.  
83.  Toward the end of the Program, FSCP is recommended to undertake a self-assessment 
of compliance with international best practices in the regulation and supervision of securities 
markets and private pension funds. This assessment could provide the basis for formulating 
another round of policy reforms to address remaining weaknesses, if any. 
b.  Strengthen the Governance of Securities Markets, Market 
Professionals, and Public Issuers 
i.  Financial Groups 
84.  The  Program  recognizes  the  potential  use  of  a  holding  company  to  achieve  both 
business and regulatory objectives. The Program also acknowledges the Government’s initiative 
to establish a task force to review the enabling environment for holding companies with special 
emphasis on their taxation, undertake stakeholder consultations, and formulate proposals in line 
with international best practices to facilitate the formation of holding companies. The Program 
supports  a  sequenced  approach  to  facilitating  the  formation  of  holding  companies  and 
subsequently  using  them  to  increase  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  financial  sector 
regulation  and  supervision.  This  will  increase  the  competitiveness  of  financial  groups  and 
reduce systemic risks in the financial sector of Pakistan.  
85.  Under the Program, the Government is to address tax policies that impede the formation 
of holding companies, as proposed by the task force. This will encourage the establishment of 
holding companies, including financial institutions, to facilitate sound risk management practices 
and supervision. Further, SECP (FSCP) will adopt regulations on the reporting requirements of 
holding companies that own or control NBFIs. The reporting should comprise (i) ownership 
structure and relationship of companies within the holding company group, (ii) disclosure of 
intercompany and related party transactions; and  (iii) public disclosure of audited financial 
reports in accordance with international accounting standards.

20    
   
ii.  Securities Law 
86.  To facilitate investor protection and capital formation, the Securities Ordinance of 1969 
needs to be replaced with a new substantive law that provides a legal framework for modern 
securities markets. SECP has to be mandated with adequate legal powers and responsibilities 
for  the  regulation  and  supervision  of  the  securities  markets  and  intermediaries,  private 
placements, public offers of listed and unlisted securities, corporate governance practices, and 
related matters, in line with international best practices. 
87.  Further, the law would introduce the concept of “best efforts” (para. 49) and other 
underwriting commitment. This should substantially increase the number of IPOs. The concept 
of underwriting should be broadened to recognize that the modern capital market demands the 
flexibility to offer either firm commitment underwritings or “best efforts” placements of securities. 
The concept of “best efforts” has been international best practice for many years. This concept 
significantly reduces the risk of investment banks in managing issues, particularly IPOs. With 
“best efforts”, the pricing of IPOs in Pakistan would tend to strike a fair balance between the 
interests of the issuer and the potential investor without being twisted by risk considerations of 
the lead manager. Prices would tend to be higher, which should, in turn, make IPOs more 
attractive for a larger number of companies. 
88.  Furthermore, the law would introduce a class of publicly tradable companies and require 
all such companies, listed and unlisted, to comply with comparable governance and disclosure 
requirements. This would eliminate the possibility of regulatory arbitrage and its harmful effects 
in the form of disincentives for listing and undermining investor protection. The class of publicly 
tradable  companies  would  include  all  companies  with  significant  public  shareholding  and 
potential to issue securities, i.e., those companies on which the regulation and supervision is to 
focus. As a result of these legal (and supporting regulatory) reforms, a significant increase in the 
number of newly listed companies can be expected. 
89.  Further under the Program, SECP (FSCP) is to issue guidelines on obtaining information 
about unlisted publicly tradable companies. Stock exchanges will continue to provide on their 
websites disclosed information of listed companies. Therefore, investors will have a better 
access to annual reports and other disclosed information of both listed and unlisted publicly 
tradable companies, which will enhance transparency and efficiency of the capital market. 
90.  Finally, the Government is to grant SECP (FSCP) the power to approve or disapprove 
audit firms authorized to audit nonbank financial companies licensed by SECP (FSCP), listed 
companies, and publicly tradable companies. This will strengthen SECP’s (FSCP’s) capability to 
ensure  quality  and  consistency  in  the  financial  information  available  to  investors  and  the 
regulator. 
iii.  Securities Institute of Pakistan 
91.  The Government is to support the completion of a feasibility study for the creation of SIP, 
which  is  currently  being  undertaken  by  the  Center  for  International  Private  Enterprise  in 
Pakistan. The study is to explore opportunities for establishing this institute as a nongovernment 
institution by industry associations and other private sector stakeholders. SIP would aim to 
increase professional standards and qualifications among securities market professional. SECP 
is recommended to financially support SIP given SIP’s potentially significant contribution in 
helping to reduce violation of laws and regulations through certification of professionals, training, 
and other measures. ADB TA will also assist in building SIP capacity (para. 108).

21 
   
92.  Further under the Program, SECP (FSCP) is also recommended to develop, together 
with SIP, a certification system for professional market participants who have completed training 
courses delivered by SIP. All securities brokers and mutual fund sales agents dealing with 
public customers should ultimately be certified by examination. As a supportive measure, SECP 
is to publish for comment on its website a new code of conduct for brokers. This new code 
would replace the existing code annexed to the Brokers and Agents Registration Rules (2001), 
and should be part of the SIP curriculum. 
iv.  Governance of Stock Exchanges 
93.  The new Securities Law would grant SECP (FSCP) authority to require a unified national 
market system in securities that may include one or more securities exchanges and alternative 
trading platforms. Such a national market system can be created through systematic exchange of 
information between various trading platforms in combination with legal and regulatory requirements 
for brokers. The system would provide for the public exposure of customer orders for the purchase 
and sale of shares to provide maximum opportunity to achieve best execution of customer orders. 
94.  Under the Program, SECP is to enhance market transparency and best execution of 
customer orders by requiring the stock exchanges to establish an intermarket surveillance 
committee. The committee would meet regularly to coordinate stock market surveillance and 
oversight of securities that are traded on more than one stock exchange and would, thus, 
institutionalize coordination (and potentially cooperation) between the exchanges. 
95.  Further, the stock exchanges are recommended to prepare plans for self-regulation for 
SECP (FSCP) approval. These plans would identify the functions to be performed by the 
exchanges in their capacity as self-regulatory organizations under the Securities Law, and 
clearly define subplans for areas such as listed companies, market surveillance, and on- and 
off-site inspections of professional market participants. These subplans should lead to the 
adherence to sound business practices and applicable laws and regulations, including financial 
responsibility requirements and quality of execution of trades on behalf of customers. They 
should also include budget estimates of the cost (and capacity) of regulatory compliance. 
96.  Toward the end of the Program, SECP (FSCP) is to conduct public consultations to 
identify remaining anticompetitive rules and regulations that undermine the creation of a national 
market system.16

100.  The Government will establish a program coordination unit in MOF, staffed with two or

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
111.  The  Program  will  facilitate  the  mobilization  of  financial  resources  for  productive 
investment and employment generation by supporting the development of corporate bond and 
equity capital markets in Pakistan. The Program will help to ensure a balanced development of 
the financial sector, which will reduce systemic vulnerabilities in the bank-dominated financial 
system. Specific benefits are as follows: 
 
(i)  By  addressing  policy  and  regulatory  constraints  to  the  issues  of  corporate 
securities, the Program will help to significantly increase the number of corporate 
bond  and  equity  issues,  both  primary  and  secondary.  This  will  facilitate  the 
mobilization  of  financial  resources  for  long-term  private  sector  investment, 
including  infrastructure  investment,  which  requires  long-term  debt  finance 
through bonds.  
(ii)  By strengthening the enabling environment for private pension funds and other 
institutional  investors,  the  Program  will  facilitate  capital  mobilization  through 
contractual savings. This is not only beneficial with regard to increasing old age 
income security. Pension reform is also a catalyst for increasing local institutional 
investment and asset diversification, resulting in improved allocation of financial 
savings. 
(iii)  By promoting the development of corporate securities markets and institutional 
investors, thereby diversifying financial instruments and broadening the investor 
base, the Program will reduce market volatility and improve the resilience of the 
financial and enterprise sectors to external shocks.   
(iv)  By strengthening regulatory and market conduct governance in capital markets, 
the  Program  will  enhance  market  efficiency  and  transparency,  and  improve 
investor protection. The establishment and institutional strengthening of FSCP

and SIP, and strengthening the self-regulatory function of stock exchanges, will 
provide these benefits. 
(v)  By addressing tax policy constraints to the formation of holding companies that 
include financial institutions, the Program will increase the competitiveness of 
financial  groups  and  the  effectiveness  of  financial  sector  regulation  and 
supervision in line with international best practices, which will, in turn, reduce 
systemic risks.  
(vi)  By supporting a more capital market-oriented privatization policy, the Program 
will (a) help to increase budget revenues, since investors will tend to pay more 
for shares if an individual offer is embedded in a transparent and credible overall 
privatization strategy; (b) support capital market development by reducing market 
volatility  through  increased  liquidity;  and  (c)  improve  the  performance  of 
enterprises by introducing market discipline to companies even if they are still 
partly state owned.  
 
B.  Impacts 
112.  A summary poverty reduction and social strategy for the Program is in Appendix 8. The 
Program is an integral component of ADB’s country strategy and program for Pakistan18 whose 
overall objective is to reduce poverty by promoting private-sector-led economic growth. The 
Program  supports  corporate  bond  market  development.  This  will  facilitate  the  financing  of 
infrastructure projects, which require long-term finance in the form of bonds. Enhanced private 
sector  infrastructure  finance  supports  poverty  reduction  goals  by  helping  to  provide  the 
population with infrastructure services and freeing up public resources needed to provide social 
services. Further, the Program supports the development of institutional investors. This will 
allow  low-income  groups  to  enter  into  well-regulated  and  protected  contractual  savings 
schemes. The outreach of the new contractual savings schemes, particularly the new pension 
products,  will  be  countrywide,  i.e.,  include  rural  areas  where  the  poor  are  concentrated. 
Furthermore, the Program helps to strengthen the governance of NBFIs and markets. This will 
increase market transparency and improve the protection of investors against fraud, which is 
particularly important for unsophisticated investors, including vulnerable parts of the population. 
As such, the Program is pro-poor in its indirect impact in the short and medium term. No 
involuntary resettlement or impact on indigenous people is expected from implementation of the 
Program (category C). The environmental implications of the Program were assessed, and no 
significant  adverse  impact  was  identified.  Both  fall  under  category  C  in  ADB’s  environmental 
classification system.  
C.  Risks  
113.  Macroeconomic stability is essential for financial sector development in general, and 
bond market development and contractual saving schemes in particular. Macroeconomic risks 
are mitigated by prudent fiscal and monetary policies and high expected economic growth rates. 
The Program has to assume that Pakistan will not suffer from any adverse geopolitical changes 
affecting  its  external  and  internal  stability.  Furthermore,  the  Program  assumes  that  the 
Government will remain strongly committed to its second generation of capital market reform 
program, which is embedded in the Government’s Medium-Term Development Framework for 
2005–2010. The presidential elections scheduled for late 2007 may result in policy changes in 
some areas. However, economic policies are unlikely to be fundamentally changed, given the 
high degree of continuity in economic policy making in Pakistan over the last decade and a 
broad consensus for economic reforms, including financial sector reform.
