SECTOR ANALYSIS 
1.  Efficiently working financial markets (especially money, foreign exchange, and capital 
markets) are integral parts of a vibrant financial system. While money markets provide financial 
intermediaries an avenue to borrow and lend short-term funds, foreign exchange markets are a 
key element of the enabling environment for international trade. Capital markets provide long-
term finance for the corporate sector (and the government). The growth and development of 
well-functioning capital markets, including markets for equity and long-term debt capital (bonds), 
convey significant economic benefits. They provide efficient savings vehicles for retail and 
institutional  investors  that  help  to  diversify  their  financial  holdings  and  facilitate  resource 
mobilization for productive investments. Further, an increased diversity of funding sources for 
corporations makes the corporate and financial sector more robust to shocks. 
 
2.  Pakistan has made progress with capital market reforms since 1998, when a year-long 
economic and financial crisis culminated in a crash of the capital market. The regulatory and 
institutional framework for the capital market has been strengthened, the financial health of 
ailing financial institutions restored, a large number of state-owned institutions privatized, and 
competition invigorated. In spite of this, domestic capital markets do not yet play a significant 
role in resource mobilization. However, the basis has been laid for a second round of capital 
market reforms that aim at turning domestic equity and bond markets into a relevant source for 
long-term finance. 
 
A.  Institutions and Structure 
 
3.  The capital market of Pakistan comprises three stock exchanges, National Clearing and 
Settlement System, Central Depositary Company, about 300 brokers, and two rating agencies. 
Further, it has many nonbank financial institutions (NBFIs), including (as of June 2006) 40 
mutual  funds;  8  investment  banks  (investment  financial  institutions),  which  also  engage  in 
brokerage  activities;  3  venture  capital  companies;  5  development  financial  institutions;1  20 
leasing companies; 31 moderabas, which offer shariah compliant financial services;2 3 housing 
finance companies; and 3 discount houses. Furthermore, 54 insurance companies play an 
increasing  role  as  institutional  investors.  The  state-owned  Central  Directorate  of  National 
Savings is the biggest institutional investor in the country, followed by State Life Insurance 
Company and Employee’s Old Age Benefits Institution. 
 
4.  Of the more than 44,000 registered companies, almost 2,800 are public, i.e., have more 
than 50 shareholders, and more than 700 are listed at one or several stock exchanges. Only 
listed companies can make public issues of securities. Listed debt securities must be rated.

D.  Factors Driving the Market 
 
24.  Privatization through the stock exchange has been a main factor driving the market, 
together  with  macroeconomic  stabilization,  and—to  a  lesser  degree—international  investor 
diversification, development of domestic institutional investors, and other structural reforms. 
 
25.  Privatization. The Government has divested a large number of SOEs since the 1990s, 
some of them by listing and partial privatization through the stock exchange(s). This has clearly 
been the main driving force for market capitalization and share prices. Among the 10 largest 
listed companies are 6 SOEs, which together account for 42% of total market capitalization. 
These SOEs are Oil and Gas Development Company (OGDCL), Pakistan Telecommunication 
Company, National Bank of Pakistan, Pakistan Petroleum, Pakistan Oilfields, and Pakistan 
State  Oil  Company.  Most  of  these  companies  were  partially  privatized  through  the  stock 
exchange  over  the  last  5  years.  OGDCL’s  initial  public  offering  (IPO),  for  instance,  was 
launched in 2003, when 5% of its shares were offered for sale through the stock exchange. A 
total of $114 million equivalent was raised. A subsequent secondary issue increased the share 
of floated OGDCL shares to 15% of total shares. As of January 2007, OGDCL accounted for 
18% of overall stock market capitalization. National Bank of Pakistan’s IPO took place in 2002, 
when 10% of its shares were offered for sale. In 2002 and 2003, an additional 13.2% of its 
shares were sold through the stock exchange. A total of $29 million equivalent was raised 
through these three issues. National Bank of Pakistan accounted for 6.5% of total market 
capitalization in January 2007. Pakistan Petroleum’s IPO, which raised $18.1 million equivalent, 
occurred in 2004. This company accounted for another 6% of total market capitalization in

shares offered; $18.1 million equivalent raised) and Kot Addu Power Company (IPO in 2005; 
20% of shares offered; $80.2 million equivalent raised). Shares of SOEs offered for sale through 
the stock market are typically heavily oversubscribed, given the expectation of subsequent

26.  Structural  Reforms.  Undeniable  progress  has  been  made  in  Pakistan  with  other 
structural reforms. These reforms have led to substantial changes such as a much higher share 
of private enterprises in- and outside the financial sector; consolidation of the NBFI subsector, 
which now consists of a smaller number of better capitalized and more efficiently managed 
entities; and a better regulatory and institutional framework for capital markets. Work is under 
way to enhance corporate governance and disclosure, which is important because both figure 
prominently in investment decisions. On the technical side, significant progress has been made 
in establishing electronic clearing and settlement systems. However, that has yet to turn the 
capital  market  into  a  significant  source  of  capital  formation.  Moderate  progress  has, 
nevertheless, been made as evidenced by the increased number of securities issues. The policy 
of SBP to increase capital requirements for banks step-by-step has, for instance, motivated a 
number of commercial banks to raised capital through bond issues (paras. 20–21).   
 
27.  Macroeconomic Environment. High economic growth, consumer demand, and higher 
corporate earnings have certainly facilitated market development in Pakistan as compared with 
the 1990s. The same applies to the monetary environment. The exchange rate and inflation 
outlook has stabilized since 1999, lengthening time horizons and reducing the cost of borrowing. 
Interest rates declined significantly during 2001–2003. Since 2004, inflation has picked up again 
and its outlook is less stable (Figure A2.5). This had a negative impact on the market for 
government bonds, particularly in 2005 when only a small portion of the PIBs offered could be 
placed (Figure A2.4). 
 
28.  The impact of higher and more volatile inflation and rising interest rates on the corporate 
bond market was mitigated by increasingly using floating rates for newly issued corporate 
bonds. Only two corporate bonds placed since 2004 had a fixed rate. Most other issues had a 
floating rate anchored to the Karachi interbank offered rate (KIBOR) with a spread of 1.5 to 3.0 
percentage points over KIBOR.14 In real terms, annual yields of such bonds were negative in 
2004 and early 2005, and subsequently increased over time to about 5%.

A.  Description of the Financial (Nonbank) Markets and Governance Program 
 
1.  In  December  2002,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  the  Financial 
(Nonbank)  Markets  and  Governance  Program  (FMGP)  loan  for  $260  million  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources and two technical assistance (TA) loans,1 each for $3 million, from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources to the Government of Pakistan. The overall goal of the FMGP 
was to facilitate private-sector-led productivity growth and social protection. This was to be 
achieved by improving the framework for mobilization of long-term resources for saving and 
investment through market-based financial instruments and institutions.  
 
2.  The  FMGP  was  to  support  the  Government’s  financial  sector  reform  agenda,  and 
development of capital markets and other nonbank financial services. The FMGP aimed to 
achieve  this  by  (i)  strengthening  investor  confidence  through  improved  governance, 
transparency,  and  investor  protection;  (ii)  increasing  the  depth  and  diversity  of  financial 
intermediation  through  new  capital  market  issues  to  mobilize  savings  and  investments; 
(iii) improving operating efficiency and risk management of intermediaries; and (iv) reducing 
financial sector vulnerabilities. 
 
3.  To achieve these objectives, reform measures were implemented, including for policy, 
governance, institutions, and market operations. The reform agenda was structured around five 
components: (i) improvement of the fiscal, interest rate, and investment policy environment; 
(ii) improvement  of  governance  of  market  participants  and  transparency  in  information 
disclosure;  (iii)  increase  in  supply  of  financial  instruments  and  improvements  in  market 
infrastructure;  (iv)  increase  in  demand  for  financial  instruments  through  development  of 
contractual  savings  and  institutional  investment;  and  (v)  development  of  related  financial 
services and institutions. 
 
B.  Overall Program Performance  
 
4.  The FMGP was a comprehensive reform effort, in that it focused on almost all aspects of 
nonbank financial sector development in Pakistan. Among others, it aimed to strengthen the 
legal and regulatory framework for securities markets, facilitate privatization through the stock 
exchanges, enact legislation on financial transactions and corporate affairs, and revamp large 
Government controlled institutions in life insurance. The FMGP established a good environment 
for change.

introduced a sense of trauma in the minds of Government officials championing the reforms.  
 
C.  Proposed Approach for Carrying the Reforms Forward 
 
7.  In view of the difficulties entailed in implementing the FMGP, the Government has asked 
ADB to cancel the pending FMPG tranche of $80 million. However, it remains committed to the 
reforms envisaged under the FMGP, but a longer time frame and a more targeted approach will 
be needed. The Government has asked ADB to design a focused capital market reform agenda 
through the proposed Second Generation Capital Market Reform Program. Specifically, the 
Government has been particular that any legislative actions should be targeted. Reforms in the 
insurance subsector and public pension system, while important for capital market reforms, will 
require greater consensus building within the Government. They should be pursued under a 
dedicated contractual savings reform initiative.  
 
8.  On the basis of the request, the Second Generation Capital Market Reform Program 
targets primarily those actions that are within the control of the Government, and specifically 
within  the  domain  of  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  of  Pakistan  (SECP).  The 
involvement and commitment of a single nodal agency such as SECP is vital for successful 
implementation of the reforms. For instance, 8 of the 9 conditions that were fulfilled for the 
incentive tranche were within SECP’s mandate.

10.  Based on extensive consultations with the Government and assessments made by staff, 
the proposed approach is prudent for supporting forward-looking reforms. It is targeted and 
recognizes the time required to change mindsets to achieve consensus and fully implement 
reforms.  The  legislative  agenda  is  modest,  confined  to  securities  markets.  However,  the 
proposed legislation would enable Pakistan to form an integrated nonbank financial sector 
supervisor  by  upgrading  SECP  to  the  Financial  Services  Commission  of  Pakistan.  The 
privatization  agenda  is  targeted,  with  support  for  the  gradual  steps  to  be  taken  for  the 
divestment  of  the  National  Investment  Trust.  ADB  will  undertake  other  more  complex 
institutional reform in the insurance and public pension subsectors separately under dedicated

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The Government’s poverty reduction and strategy paper (PRSP), completed in December 2003, rests on four pillars: (i) 
achieving high and broad-based economic growth focusing particularly on the rural economy, while maintaining 
macroeconomic stability; (ii) improving governance and consolidating devolution; (iii) investing in human capital with a 
renewed emphasis on effective delivery of basic social services; and (iv) bringing the poor and vulnerable and 
backward regions into the mainstream of development, and making marked progress in reducing existing inequalities.  
 
The first pillar comprises several policy and structural elements including reforming the financial sector, developing the capital 
market, streamlining the regulatory framework, providing supportive infrastructure, and developing a rural development 
strategy. 
 
Poverty  reduction  is  an  encompassing  objective  of  Pakistan’s  Medium-Term  Development  Framework  (MTDF)   
2005–2010. The MTDF subsumes the Government’s PRSP. The MTDF lists growth of the private sector, development 
of privatization in infrastructure (which requires long-term debt financing through corporate bonds), as well as capital 
market development as important goals. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                      Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The Pakistan Economic Survey 2005–2006, released in June 2006, reports that the percentage of the population living 
below the poverty line has fallen from 34.46% in 2001 to 23.90% in 2004/05, a decline of 10.6 percentage points. The 
percentage of population living below the poverty line in rural areas has declined from 39.26% to 28.10%, while that in 
urban areas has declined from 22.69% to 14.9%. Rural poverty declined by 11.16 percentage points and urban 
poverty by 7.79 percentage points. A strong economic growth (7.5% average) for 3 years in a row, a large inflow of 
remittances (over $4 billion per annum) in recent years, and many other interventions contributed to the decline in 
poverty. Notwithstanding this development, around 36.45 million people in Pakistan still live below the poverty line. 
Further reduction in poverty is a major challenge for the Government. 
 
Despite the progress made in implementing capital market reforms, the contribution of the sector to private sector 
development has been as weak as its role in capital mobilization for productive investment. The Program will enhance 
the capital markets’ capacity to carry out its intermediation role effectively by deepening reforms, and strengthening the 
enabling policy, legal, regulatory, and institutional environment for nonbank financial institutions and markets. This will 
improve companies’ access to finance; facilitate people’s access to financial services, particularly pension products; 
and help to protect vulnerable parts of the population against fraud:  
 
(i)  The Program aims at removing the major constraints to the development of the corporate bond market by 
reducing the costs of issuing bonds, simplifying the underlying procedures, and supporting the development of a 
benchmark yield curve for pricing corporate bonds. Corporate bond market development will facilitate the financing of 
infrastructure projects, which requires long-term finance in the form of bonds (fixed-income securities). This will 
support poverty reduction goals by helping to provide the population with infrastructure services and freeing up public 
resources needed to provide social services. Further, the Program will support balanced development of the financial 
sector, which will make the financial sector less vulnerable to crisis, by which low-income groups of the population tend 
to be more seriously affected than high-income groups. 
 
(ii)  The limited availability of contractual savings (e.g., complementary pension schemes) has made the weakest 
part of the population more vulnerable to uncertain events. The Program will support development of institutional 
investors by improving the legal and regulatory framework of voluntary private pension and occupational saving 
schemes. This will allow low-income groups of the population to enter into well-regulated and protected contractual 
savings schemes, access the capital market through these schemes, and benefit from higher returns of capital market 
instruments. The outreach of new pension products, for which the Program will provide an enabling framework, will be 
countrywide, i.e., include rural areas where the poor are concentrated. 
 
(iii)  The Program will help to strengthen the governance of nonbank financial institutions and markets. This will 
increase market transparency and the protection of investors against fraud,  which is particularly important for 
unsophisticated investors, including vulnerable parts of the population.
